PURPOSE

To develop a hazardous materials process safety management program that will protect the employees and neighbors from catastrophic releases, minimize lesser incidents, and comply with regulations by training all personnel in safe handling techniques and rapid emergency response.


EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Employees will be named to teams to implement and maintain the program.  The teams will include members of the operations and maintenance departments including supervisors and managers.  The goal is to have those involved with the chlorine process placed on teams.

The completed plan will be available for all employees.


TEAMS

Process Hazard Analysis
Heath Keelin OIT
Danny Ogle OIT

Mechanical Integrity
Leonard Warren Maintenance Mechanic

Compliance Audit
Gary Turley, Project Manager
Henry Snedigar, Operation's Supervisor
                           
CHLORINE DISINFECTION PROCESS SAFETY ANALYSIS

HAZARDS

TOXICITY
Chlorine, in and of itself, is not toxic.  It is, however, classified as a poisonous gas because when it combines with moisture it produces corrosive acids.  If inhaled the gas combines with moisture in the body to form acids that irritate and burn bodily tissues.  Chlorine inhalation can cause lung damage and death from pulmonary edema.


Exposure limits: TWA = 0.5 parts per million.  STEL = 1.0 ppm

Eye effects: 1 ppm can cause redness, tearing and irritation.  Exposure to greater concentrations of vapor or to liquid can cause burns and blindness.
Skin effects: Exposure to liquid will cause burns.  Exposure to gas can cause burns.

Other toxic effects: Inhalation is the major route of exposure. Exposure to 3-6 ppm can cause irritation of the upper respiratory tract, headaches, and coughing.  10 ppm will cause severe irritation of respiratory tract.  15-20 ppm can cause nausea, vomiting, dizziness, shortness of breath, and chest pain.  Pulmonary edema and chemical pneumonia can follow.  Exposures to greater concentrations can cause unconsciousness and death.

Exposure to 0.5 ppm for 8 hours or 1.0 ppm for 4 hours can cause transient reduction in pulmonary capacity.

Chlorine is not listed as a carcinogen by NIP, IARC or OSHA.


Chronic effects: Chronic exposure is unlikely because of the disagreeable odor of concentrations of even 1 ppm.  Tests indicate that intermittent exposures to concentrations of that level caused no observable adverse health effects.

Oral ingestion is unlikely because chlorine exists as a gas at ambient temperatures.


*See Appendix I for additional information on the chlorine MSDS.


PHYSICAL PROPERTIES AND DESCRIPTION
Chlorine is an element of the halogen family.

Molecular Weight: 70.9    Specific gravity (liquid): 1.467
Boiling point: -34o C    Melting point:  -101o C

Chlorine is stored under pressure as liquid in one ton containers.  Liquid chlorine is brownish and about 1.5 times as heavy as water.  Chlorine is removed from the containers as a gas.  Chlorine exists as greenish/yellowish gas at normal temperatures and has a sharp disagreeable odor.  Chlorine gas occupies 450 times the volume of its liquid state.   Chlorine gas is approximately 2.5 times as heavy as air.

REACTIVITY AND CORROSITIVITY DATA

Chlorine is stable.

Chlorine is neither explosive or flammable, but will support combustion.  Dry chlorine is not corrosive but it easily combines with water to form corrosive hypochlorous and hydrochloric acids.

INCOMPATIBILITY DATA
May cause fire and/or explosion upon contact with turpentine, ether, ammonia, hydrocarbons, certain metal hydrides, carbides, nitrides, oxides, sulfides, phosphates, or easily oxidized materials.


PROCESS TECHNOLOGY

Chlorine is used at the Pampa Wastewater Treatment Plant, in the manner mandated by state and federal laws, to disinfect treated municipal wastewater by inactivating potential pathogens.  Although the exact process is not completely understood, chlorine is thought to penetrate the cell wall causing destruction of the organism.

INVENTORY
Maximum:  3 (1 ton cylinders)        Minimum: 1    Operating: 1

STORAGE
Ton cylinders are placed between roller chocks that are bolted to the floor of the storage room or on rollers on the chlorine scales.  Chlorine must be stored under pressure to maintain its liquid state (See boiling point above).  The pressure varies with ambient temperature.  At 50o F for example, the pressure inside the cylinders is 60 psi.  Pressures increase as temperatures increase.  The cylinders are equipped with a fusible plug that acts as a pressure release if ambient temperature reaches 158o F. To avoid excessive temperatures the storage room is open on two sides. 

Since chlorine gas is removed from the cylinders by vacuum there are no pressure lines in the storage room.

SAFETY LIMITS
Temperature:    Upper..120o F    .    Lower..N/A
(In reality temperatures in the storage room are those of the outside because the room is not enclosed on two sides.)

Pressure:        Upper  250 psi        Lower..N/A
(Pressure would be approaching 318 psi before the fusible plug(s) give.)

Exceeding 158o F. or 318 psi would cause a release of chlorine gas that would threaten the safety of employees and physical integrity of any metals contacted in the presence of water.     

ELECTRICAL CLASSIFICATION
N/A


EQUIPMENT UNITS
3 chlorine ton cylinders**
3 scales capable of holding one cylinder each*
1 remote readouts, one for each scale
1 manifolds with hookups for one cylinders
1 regulators*
2 chlorinators*
2 eductors (injectors)*
1 cable hoist for moving chlorine cylinders
2 self contained breathing units**

* See Appendix II for detailed information on these equipment units.
** See Appendix III for detailed information on these equipment units.

PHYSICAL PROCESS
Chlorine is purchased in ton cylinders, two cylinders per delivery.  Cylinders are removed from the delivery truck and placed in roller chocks in the chlorine room.  Empty cylinders are loaded on the delivery truck and returned to the supplier.  (See procedure for loading and unloading cylinders.)

Removal of gas from the cylinders is accomplished by means of a vacuum generated by a venturi tube (eductor).  Service water is pumped across a venturi tube increasing the velocity causing a drop in pressure.  There is an aperture in the venturi tube connected to a line to a v-notch chlorinator which in turn is connected to a regulator affixed to the uppermost valve on the chlorine cylinder.  The vacuum withdraws chlorine gas from the cylinder.

The rate of removal is controlled in one of two ways.  Manually, dosage is changed by adjusting a rotometer.  Automatically, the dosage can be linked to a percentage of the effluent flow.  The chlorinators and eductors are plumbed in parallel and valved so that application can be made at the secondary clarifiers (along the perimeter of the launders).

The chlorination at the secondary clarifiers is for proper kill of pathogenic organisms through the chlorine contact basins with a limit set forth from the permit issued by the Environmental Protection Agency and Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission for the Pampa WWTP.  Chlorine residual of the final effluent has permitted requirements of 0.02 mg/L.

Chlorination along the perimeter of the secondary clarifiers aids in the removal of algae accumulation in the launders.  If not removed regularly algae causes a false chlorine demand in the chlorine contact basin, which may lead to inadequate disinfection.
The feed to the influent channels for pre-chlorination is not normally used.  The feed rate depends on quantity and quality of water being treated.  Sunlight, rising temperatures, increase of organic loading, Turbidity, algae, and filamentous bacteria blooms can all require additional chlorine.  Chlorine dosage is normally measured in pounds per 1000 mg/L of MLVSS (Mixed Liquor Volatile Suspended Solids).  Chlorine residual is recorded daily at the outfall of the final effluent. 

For the Pampa Wastewater Treatment Plant the daily effluent residual can not exceed 0.02 mg/l, nor can the monthly average exceed 0.02 mg/l without a violation being reported to the EPA and TNRCC.

The in-service chlorine cylinder is placed on a scale for monitoring of pounds used.  Dial read outs, located in the chlorine room, provide constant monitoring of the total weight on the scales.  Each day during morning rounds (between 08:00 and 08:30) the weight is noted and the pounds used during the previous day calculated.  Chlorine consumption is entered in the process control spreadsheet as pounds used per 24 hours. 

The regulator affixed to the cylinders are valve and heating devices that open when vacuum is applied and close automatically when the cylinder is empty.  The system is assembled to switch from the empty cylinder to the ready one.  Since the chlorine is stored as liquid under pressure in a partially filled cylinder (80% full at 68o F.= 1 ton.) chlorine gas is drawn off the top of the cylinder.  If, when the cylinder is placed on line a tiny amount of liquid chlorine enters the regulator assembly the heater converts it to gas.  

The regulator is attached to the in-service cylinder. The empty cylinder is then removed from the scale and is replaced by a full cylinder. (See the procedure for changing cylinders.)

CHEMICAL PROCESS
When chlorine is added to water the chemical reaction is:
      Cl2    +   H2O  -->       HOCl     +    HCl
    chlorine            water               hypochlorous acid          hydrochloric acid                         
Hypochlorous acid is the primary disinfectant and is thought to inactivate bacteria, viruses, and most protozoa by penetrating the cell wall.  Certain protozoa that form cysts in adverse environments can, however, be quite resistant to chlorination.

Some of the hypochlorous acid dissociates as follows:

     HOCl      -->        H+        +           OCl-     
hypochlorous acid                      hydrogen ion                    hypochlorite ion


Hydrochloric acid also dissociates in water:
        HCl     -->       H+         +           Cl-
 hydrochloric acid                      hydrogen                       chlorine  ion   

Chlorine is an oxidizing agent and will combine with impurities, if present, in the water to form chlorine compounds such as chloramine.  Feeding of additional chlorine destroys some of these compounds (A procedure known as breakpoint chlorination).  


VENTILATION
The chlorine building is open on the east and west ends and provides for open cirulation 


SAFETY EQUIPMENT
A bottle of ammonia is provided near cylinders to manually check for leaks.  (Ammonia fumes and chlorine gas combine to form a white vapor.)

Personal protective equipment is located in the office building. Equipment includes boots, gloves, and rain gear in addition to the self-contained breathing units. The two units are in a black plastic transportable case and are used for off-property confined space inspections and emergencies. 

A chlorine "B" repair kit is located just inside the administration building front door closet.  

Please see the emergency response plan for further safety information.

*See Appendix III for alarm locations and storage layout.

INSTRUMENTS
Chlorine residuals are checked daily by grab samples using the Hach DP 100 meter.  A chlorine reagent is added to a 5 ml sample cell which is placed in the spectrophotometer for analysis.

MATERIALS OF CONSTRUCTION
See mechanical drawings for piping schematic.


CHLORINATION PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

INTRODUCTION
A "What-If" method is used to identifying hazards.  We have assumed only one operator on duty unless a malfunction occurs during work, such as changing cylinders, that requires a two man team.

The only place that chlorine is under pressure is in the cylinders themselves.  Therefore, the principal hazards involved are the integrity of the cylinders and cylinder valves.

PLANT SITING
The plant is located on the north bank of Red Deer Creek, at a point 3400 feet northeast of State Highway Loop 171, approximately 3.5 miles northeast of the intersection of U.S. Highway 60 and State Highway 273 in Gray County, Texas

Ground is rolling, stable, and above the flood plain.


INTERNAL FACTORS

CHLORINATORS, EDUCTORS, PIPING
What-if a leak developed on the piping?
Because chlorine gas is removed from the cylinders by vacuum a failure of the vacuum lines would: (A) Cause the regulators on the cylinders to fail closed; and (B) Cause outside air to be sucked into the lines.  No hazard exists.

What-if a chlorinator fails?  
A vacuum failure causes the regulator to fail closed.  No hazard results.

What-if an eductor (injector) fails?  
A vacuum failure causes the regulator to fail closed.  No hazard results.

REGULATORS
What-if a regulator fails?  
Regulator is designed to fail closed.  No hazard results.

What-if the regulator heater fails?  
Regulator still functions.

CYLINDER VALVES
What-if a cylinder valve will not open?
Valve wrench can be struck sharply with the palm of the hand.  If valve will still not open the supplier is called and the cylinder is exchanged.  No hazard results.

What-if a cylinder valve will not close properly?
If the leak is minor the valve cap can be put on and the valve can be opened and closed.  The handle can be struck sharply with the palm of the hand to seat it.  Check valve to see if leak still exists.  If the leak is bad enough for self-contained breathing units to be donned the fire department and or Chemtrec will be called.  Operators can don breathing units and enter the storage room with fireman and repeat procedure outlined above.
What-if a cylinder valve breaks off while operator is opening or closing it?
Operators while already wearing SCBA leave room, call fire department and Chemtrec.  After fire department arrives, leak can be stopped by at least two people wearing the proper personal protection equipment and hammering a drift pin from the repair "B" kit in the opening left by the broken valve. 

CYLINDERS
What-if liquid chlorine appears in the hypalon tubing when cylinder is placed in service?
Close valve, use hair dryer to gently warm tube until chlorine dissipates.  Remove regulator, rotate cylinder 180o, reattach regulator and place in service.  

What-if liquid chlorine still appears in the hypalon tubing?
Take cylinder off line and inform supplier of defective cylinder (probably over-filled) and request a replacement cylinder.

What-if a cylinder develops a leak in a side wall?
Fire Department and Chemtrec must be called.  After the fire department arrives the leak can be repaired by two people using the repair "B" kit, while wearing the proper personal protection equipment.

What-if a catastrophic failure of a cylinder occurs?
Fire department and Chemtrec must be called.  Operator will notify project manager or next in command.  Pampa police will evacuate nearby area as necessary.  

EXTERNAL FACTORS

VANDALISM
What-if attempt to vandalize occurs?
Storage area is not lockable.  Operators are on duty only 9 hrs. per day Monday-Friday and 4 hrs on weekends.  It would be possible to break into the plant and storage area.

FLOOD
Neither event is likely in view of plant location.

Tornadoes

At present there are no means of strapping the cylinders to their cradles.  The cylinders are held in place by their own weight.

Emergency access to storage area is good via driveway around the plant.

*See Appendix IV for detailed map of area and prevailing wind directions
CHLORINE INCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no catastrophic or personal injury related occurrences due to chlorine release at the plant.


TRAINING POLICY FOR OUTSIDE CONTRACTORS
AND EMPLOYEES FROM OTHER DEPARTMENTS

STATEMENT OF POLICY
All outside contractors and employees from other departments will be informed of the chlorine storage and given appropriate training.

TRAINING REQUIRED
Outside personnel will be informed of appropriate escape routes. They will also be given basic information as to the odor, appearance, and hazards of chlorine.

Additionally, the nature of the process, process diagram, materials used in piping, and potential hazards will be explained.

HOT WORK PERMITS
Hot work permits will be issued for any welding or cutting and special instruction on the effect of chlorine at high temperatures on steel and other metals as necessary.

EMPLOYEE TRAINING PROGRAM

Every employee that has need to adjust chlorine feed rates, change cylinders, maintain chlorine feed equipment, or do construction work in the chlorine room will be trained to recognize any and all emergencies and how to respond.  They will also be trained in use of personal protection equipment, including self-contained breathing units.

Permanent employees will be trained to understand the process and use of chlorine leak repair kits.  

TRAINING FREQUENCY

BI-ANNUAL TRAINING

Review of emergency response.
Donning breathing units.
Cylinder changing
Escape routes


ANNUAL TRAINING

Repair kit use.
Process review

EMERGENCY RESPONSE TO CHLORINE Leak

Chlorine leak is observed.

    A.    Look for yellow-green cloud of chlorine gas near floor.

            a)    If no cloud observed, check for odor.

            b)    If no odor noted, enter area and recheck carefully for smell of chlorine.

            c)    If no chlorine is detected or odor is very slight check cylinder fittings for leaks with ammonia bottle.

d)  No leaks! Return to normal operations

    B.    If moderate leak is detected, return to administration building, notify Project Manager or next in command and have them call the Fire Department.

    C.    If leak is more severe call Pampa Fire Department at 911

    D.    If leak is catastrophic notify Pampa Police that neighbors may have to be evacuated.

Do not attempt to repair leak before help arrives!

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
CITY of PAMPA WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT

General Facility Information

The Pampa Wastewater Treatment Plant located off of Highway Loop 171, east of the City in Gray County.  The facility is owned by the City of Pampa and operated by Operations Management International, Inc (OMI).  Capacity of the facility is 3.0 million gallons per day (MGD).  Presently on average, the wastewater treatment plant processes 2.2 MGD of wastewater.  The plant utilizes an activated sludge oxidation ditch process that operates 24 hours per day year round.  The plant is staffed 9 hours per day Monday through Friday and on week ends 4 hours per day.  A maximum of 3 tons of chlorine gas in one ton containers are stored onsite with 2 containers being connected and online at any one time.  

Ongoing safety training programs cover all phases of plant operation from maintenance and operations safety to safe handling of chlorine.  OMI also conducts formal training as well as onsite training during normal daily operations.  OMI also using outside vendors to conduct safety training relating to plant safety and chemical safety.  Due to this safety training, this plant has not had any significant chlorine release or accidents in the last five years.


Hazard Assessment Information

40 CFR Part 68, Subpart B - Hazard Assessment, outlines a specific set of criteria required to be used in the modeling of worst case and most probable case release scenarios.  Worst case and most probable case scenario modeling was completed using Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA) software.

To complete most probable case and worse case scenario plume models, the default level of concern for chlorine was set at levels established in accordance with EPA and American Industrial Hygiene Association standards.  The resulting plume indicates a level where individuals would be able to take protective actions without suffering any serious health effects from a chemical exposure during a one hour

or less time period.  Most probable case and worse case scenario plume analysis results are conservative estimates based on the ALOHA software, using RMP release and meteorological requirements.


Prevention Program Information

The Pampa Wastewater Treatment Plant processes 2.2 MGD of domestic sewage.  OMI has an on-going training plan that involves both classroom and on-the-job training.  All new employees who will be required to handle chlorine are trained in chlorine safety and undergo Right-to-Know training.  
Any small controlled leak will be handled by plant personnel and all other leaks will be handled by the Pampa Fire Department.


Emergency Response Information 

A controlled release of the chlorine product located at the wastewater treatment plant, will be defined as the escape of gas to the atmosphere in small, non-reportable quantities, resulting from standard operating procedures of connecting or disconnecting chlorine containers and standard maintenance procedures on the plant's chlorine equipment.

An uncontrolled release of chlorine gas which will require the implementation of the emergency response procedures is defined as any release other than those examples defined as similar to controlled releases.  Emergency responses to the treatment plant will be made by the Pampa Fire Department, in accordance with the facility emergency plan and the Gray County Emergency Response Plan.  If uncontrolled release conditions warrant such actions, shelter-in-place, evacuation, and public warning will be implemented by the Pampa/Gray County Office of Emergency Management.  Any uncontrolled release of chlorine gas shall be subject to an after action incident investigation by the City of Pampa, OMI, and exclusive State and Federal regulatory agencies for review and oversight.
